Posts.Title: Can you believe John Edwards? waterlily Daffodil

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 09:26PM lewisfamily503 wrote: I honestly think a BIG problem is the hormones, ladies, especially for those of us going through menopause.  However, I had  what I think was really a breakdown about ten years ago due to a lack of sleep.  I still don't know what caused it.  But I just stopped sleeping. I would go to bed at night and then spend the entire night staring at the ceiling.  After about two weeks, I finally went to my doctor.  By that time I was a total wreck.  They took my blood pressure it was like, 160 over 100.  YIKES!!!  So my doctor gave me some tranquilizers and told me NO ALCOHOL!!! I took the pill and slept like a baby!  However, it took about a month to calm down. I was just a nervous wreck. Sleep makes ALL the difference. I panic still when I don't sleep. I worry that the long stretch of sleepless nights will return once again and I will have another breakdown.  But so far, I only have short streches without sleep.  I think it's okay to take sleep aids for the short term.  I do agree that we should try to exercise and go easy on the alcohol.  I have found that drinking might help me to go to sleep initially but then I wake up in the wee hours and I can't get back to sleep. UGH!!  Good luck ladies.  I hope you find your way to sweet dreams! Anne

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2008 09:17PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Hi Renee,  By the way, I am also from Oregon--GO DUCKS!!!  It was exactly a year ago when I had my biopsy and faced breast cancer.  It does make one a bit crazy and just a bit discombulated!!!!   I did not have your diagnosis. My breast cancer was DCIS--and not invasive.  Even so, I had ten years of abnormal mastectomies.  I had biopsies, met with oncologists and talked about various drug therapies, etc....... Years ago I decided if the real thing actually happened, I wanted my breasts GONE!!  Well, a year ago, my surgeon called with the news. It was an easy decision for me. Now, a year later, I feel SOOO at peace!!! My god-given breasts are gone, but, oh well!!!  I do NOT have breast cancer, and my doctors tell me I am 99 % cured!!!!    I have perky "foobs" and I am just plain HAPPY!!!!!   I was never attached to my "real" breast so this was such an easy decision, and I understand if you feel differently than me, but it was just the best choice for me!    Good luck, no matter what you choose, and please feel free to PM me and ask any questions you may have.  It is TRULY amazing how easy a mastectomy is.  It sounded so scary to me when I was considering it, but it was so easy and worked out so well for me!!  Hugs to you! Anne in Oregon

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2008 12:49PM lewisfamily503 wrote: I SO appreciate this thread since I am also a teacher (music k-5). The PE teacher at my school emailed me and asked me what she should tell the kids since they have been asking where I am ( I haven't been there since before winter break). I see all of the kids at our school (550) so there are bound to be some who have struggled with cancer in their immediate families, and I hate to upset them further. Anyway, I do agree that honesty with children is the best way to go. Still, I have decided to keep it as brief as possible. One thing about kids--they don't need lengthy explanations. They just want reassurance! I can't wait to get back to them (the day after MLK will be my first day back-YAY!)

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 03:20PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Dear JIll,  Is there anyone who could help you out for just a few nights?  I cannot imagine not having someone there to help out at first........My husband helped me SOOO much with my drains, pain medication, etc..  Your son is most likely a great kid,but I woudn't put him through  this as far as being a care giver.  I would definitely recommend having someone there for at least a few days.  If you have no other recourse, then by all means, hire a nurse or some sort of aide.  I am hoping you will have someone to take care of you.....God bless!!!  Anne
Posts.Title: How Long in Hospital after Bi-Later with Reconstruction? Mocity mom_of_2

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 02:06PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Just chiming in! I have been dealing with these issues since 2001 and this past year (Oct. 2007, I was given the news of DCIS. After extensive research and also, after talking to many women whom I know locally who have dealt with DCIS, I opted for a bilateral mastectomy. It feels like a no brainer for me, but i respect and understand each woman's decision based on their history and comfort level. I do NOT miss my breasts in the least! I am in the middle of my reconstruction, having had the mastectomy back in December and the exchange surgery is scheduled for June. I am SO at peace with the removal of my breasts and I LOVE my new "foobs" (even though I am awaiting my final implants!!! As I have said in previous posts, I was a VERY large breasted gal (DD) so I am very happy to be a B cup at this point and I don't bounce! I can wear tops with spaghetti straps and things that NEVER in my wildest dreams could I have ever worn! My final pathology came back with clean margins on the dcis side! My other side had atypical cells so even though it wasn't dcis I am confident that it was at risk for future problems, so it was ALL good!! Plus, since I opted for the mastectomy, I didn't have to have radiation which was a whole 'nother can of worms!! Whatever you decide, I wish you the best of luck! Anne
Posts.Title: MASTECTOMY FOR DCIS thetrumumshow Noni

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 03:50PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Count me in for the itching.  Mine is not really relieved with scratching since it is in a numb area.  The WORST part is when it happens and you are with people and you can't do anything.  Luckily it is sporadic.  I also get phantom pains that come and go.  And......since I am complaining, I will add that I still have muscle tightness, especially when I am in bed.  I am hoping this will all pass.  After all, it's not even a year since my bilateral mastectomies.  I guess it's just a price we have to pay.  I try to ignore this all and not worry!!! Anne

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2008 04:13PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Hi Audric! Let me the first to welcome you to a wonderful community of women who represent a vast bank of knowledge of just about every breast cancer topic you can think of! I just wanted to let you know that we will be here for you, no matter what you find out. I remember my first biopsy. I was definitely stressed, but it went really smoothly. Rest assured that your doctor will take good care of you! Are you going under general anesthesia? It sounds like maybe you are. I know I had that for my surgery. It is hard not to eat or drink anything, but they usually let you have a "sip" of water if you are parched! You can do it! The other thing I want to say is even if something is found, it is amazing at how many women are treated for breast cancer and go on to lead long long lives after their treatment. So, try not to worry and know that we are all here to support you! Hugs from Oregon, Anne

Posts.Title: mastectomy photos shrink buchanwebb1

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2008 12:27PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Hi Girls! My exchange was yesterday and I'm back! YAY!!!!!!! For me, this surgery was pretty easy compared with the mastectomy back in December. It was shorter, but still about 2 hours long. Evidently, I developed a lot of scar tissure internally around the implants, and that had to all be removed. So, my PS had to put interrnal stitches in to hold my new implants in place. Also, and this is kind of funny, I guess I am "asymmetrical" and when he put the the same size implants in, they didn't match. It seems my chest wall isn't even or something. SO.....I now have a 400 cc implant on my right side and a 450 cc implant on my left side. That should be interesting!!! I am definiitely in pain--I am taking percocet about every 3 hours or so, but I am hoping that won't last too long. They gave me A LOT of pain pills (I thiink I have over 150 total from all the bottles I have been given in the past six months) so that is good, I guess?? My DH is just awesome. We are teachers and just out of school for the year so he is doting on me. He was SO worried about the surgery and everything. What a sweet guy! I hope you are all doing great. If your surgery is still coming up, GOOD LUCK!!! Hugs, Anne
Posts.Title: Surgery in June? carollyn Kymberlyn

Posts.Content: May 26, 2008 04:48PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Joining this group too! My surgery will be to exchange my muscle expanders with the silicone gel implants. SOOOO excited!!!! My date is June 12. I will let you all know how it turns out! VERY excited to be going smaller (from DD to B or small C)!! Anne
Posts.Title: Surgery in June? carollyn Kymberlyn

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 10:25PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Hi Vickie,  I have a friend who's mom and sister died of breast cancer.  At a young age (in her early 30s) she had a double mastectomy.  That was over 20 years ago and she is still alive and happy and healthy.  Given your history, I don't think it's at all overly cautious to be considering such a drastic surgery.  In the end, it's your decision and your decision alone.  It IS a big decision.  I had a double mastectomy one year ago and I only had DCIS.  I am sure some people think I over-reacted, but I feel so at peace with my choice.  I don't worry anymore.  It hasn't been an easy road, though.  I had a lot of pain during my reconstruction.  I still have weird occasional twitches and phantom pains and tightness in my chest muscles, plus numbness.  I think this might not ever be gone, so it's something I am learning to live with. Still....... I would choose the same thing if I had to do it all over again.  Do your research.  Listen to the women here.  There are compelling arguments for going either way.  In the end, do what is in your heart and it will be the right choice for you!  Hugs, Anne

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2008 11:28PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Hi Dottie, I was diagnosed with "atypical hyperplasia" back in 2001. At that time, they tried to do the need core biopsy, but I was a lousy candidate, due to claustrophobia and not wanting to be "still" that long on my tummy!! So, they did a surgical biopsy and found these cells. I was referred to an oncologist who wanted me to go on tamoxifen but I ultimately chose not to, due to the side effects. This last October, I had yet another biopsy and this time, the found DCIS, and so I had a double mastectomy, after which they found additional DCIS in the breast that had the biopsy. The other breast had "suspicious cells' that might or might not have developed into DCIS. My advice would be to research the hell out of this and make your own decision, based on your research and your gut! For me, it was the mastectomy, but many many women opt for other treatments including radiation and drug therapies. It really is a crap shoot in my honest opinion, but for me, just getting rid of the threat made me feel better!! Good luck to you! Anne

Posts.Content: May 3, 2008 04:44PM lewisfamily503 wrote: Just echoing all the lovely ladies here. Breast Cancer Org is THE place to be for love, support and friendship. The advice and support here is priceless. And heaven help those who threaten this place (like scammers for example!) for the wrath of these women is something to behold, kind of like a mama bear protecting her young!) On your worst day possible, the sisters here will be there for you. I have laughed, cried and been touched deeply by all of and will forever be thankful for this wonderful place! Anne

Posts.Title: Heather needs support LuAnnH heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2008 12:23AM lewisfamily503 wrote: Your post pretty much describes why I opted for my bilateral masectomies.  i will admit it wasn't the easiest of roads, but I am VERY confident with the final outcome.  I feel like I am done with BC and  the downside isn't that bad.  You will have scars, possibly some ongoing nerve pain ( I have that from time to time) and you have to decide between saline and silcone if you reconstruct) but still, given the alternative, I will take it!  I am now post exchange surgery, and I am so very happy!!! Obviously, I am cancer-free (at this point) and as a bonus, I have these wonderful, albeiit not real, foobs that are so very perky!!!  Where's the downside????????     The scars are fading quickly and although I am still deciding on nipples, whateever I decide will be better than the alternative.   I look upon this as a blessing.  I hated my breasts.  34 DD was just too big!!!!!!   This defintely is a decision you will need to make based upon your individual situation.  Go with your gut and your needs.........don't let others sway you.  Listen to your heart! Anne
Posts.Title: seriously considering another mastectomy paige-allyson Erica

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 12:43AM lewisfamily503 wrote: Okay--I wasn't gonna share this publicly but here goes! I REALLY wanted a shower. So we called the advice nurse and she said I could shower with my drains IF i covered up the insertion points really well. She recommended "Press and Seal" wrap. So my wonderful husband rushed out to the grocery store to purchase some. He returned and said, "Honey, I have good news and bad news. The good news is I got the press and seal wrap. The bad news is all they had was the "holiday" kind. So there I was, buck naked except for that holiday wrap around my middle, complete with Frosty, Rudolph and Santa adorning me. I took one look in the mirror and could not stop laughing, and it hurt SO bad to laugh. Anyway, here's hoping that you don't suffer the same indignity!! Anne
